Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds William Ross Waldrip of the University of Arizona to conduct a research project, entitled "Using volcanic rocks in southern Tibet to understand continental collisions," during the summer of 2012 at China University of Geosciences in Beijing, China. The host scientist is Wang Chengshan.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to use the geochemistry of volcanic rocks erupted during the collision of India with Asia to better understand deep earth processes during continental collisions.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

This project aims to explore how the geochemistry of volcanic rocks changes during the transition from oceanic plate subduction (i. e. the Nazca plate subducting under western South America) to continental collision and its plate tectonic implications. Within the archetypal India-Asia collision zone in southern Tibet, the Gangdese continental margin arc records continuous volcanic activity during the transition from oceanic subduction to India-Asia continental collision (69-43 Ma). These rocks provide a rare geological window into processes active early in the evolution of continental collision at the roots of the mountain building event. The goal is to create robust data sets for the Gangdese arc and new tectonic models that may explain its evolution during the initiation of continental collision

My host and I were unable to secure work permits for Tibet in order for the fieldwork to be performed as proposed. This is not unexpected as it is often difficult to secure these permits in the best of years. I was able to contact another Chinese colleague who I have worked with in the past and he was able to collect these necessary samples for me. 67 samples were collected from 5 separate transects of the Linzizong Volcanic Succession from Namling in the west to the Linzhou Basin north of Lhasa. These samples have been shipped to to the U.S. and are currently being analyzed.

            Knowing that official work permits were not guaranteed I brought the initial sample suite that I collected in the summer of 2011. I have almost completed work on these samples and planned on finishing the lab work at China University of Geosciences, Beijing. I was able to secure time and assistance in determining the major element composition of these rocks and combine this with the trace element, crystallization age and Hafnium isotopic data that I have previously determined. Unfortunately the facilities to measure the Sr and Nd isotope ratios and addition rock dating were not available and are being completed at the University of Arizona.
